questions.text: Which structure contributes to the virulence of Neisseria gonorrhoeae by preventing phagocytosis and assisting in attachment to host cells?
An obligate aerobe will exhibit which of the following features during thioglycolate broth incubation?
questions.correct_answer: C. Growth only at the top

questions.text: Which of the following culture media is selective for Gram-negative enteric bacteria?
Which of the following is a chemically defined synthetic medium?
Which method is best for determining bacterial population growth over time in a liquid culture?
Which genetic mechanism allows Streptococcus pneumoniae to acquire a capsule and evade immunity?
Which bacterial toxin increases intracellular cyclic AMP by activating adenylate cyclase?
Which of the following stains is most appropriate to visualize Mycobacterium leprae in tissue samples?
Which culture method is best for isolating and identifying obligate intracellular bacteria?
Which of the following bacterial toxins acts via inhibition of the 60S ribosomal subunit?
A 1 µm organism with no cell wall, resistant to βlactams, appears as a "fried egg" colony on PPLO agar. Which stain is least useful?
Which of the following is a differential medium that distinguishes between lactose fermenters and no fermenters?
Which of the following microscopes provides the highest magnification and resolution?
Which of the following bacterial genetic elements is capable of integrating into the host chromosome and later excising itself to enter a lytic cycle?
Which staining technique is best used to demonstrate the presence of bacterial capsules?
A Gram- positive rod forms black colonies with a ground glass appearance on PEMBA medium. The organism is most likely:
Which of the following structures is found only in Gram-negative bacteria?
The best method to sterilize heat-sensitive liquids like vaccines and serum is:
A typical gene transfer that requires bacteriophage as a vector is:
The phase where bacterial death equals growth, with nutrient depletion and toxic accumulation, is:
Which antibody is primarily involved in mucosal immunity?
The complement pathway that is activated by antigen-antibody complexes is:
Which cytokine is primarily responsible for class switching to IgE production in allergic reactions?
Which immune cell type is central to the delayed type of hypersensitivity (DTH) response?
In agglutination reactions, latex agglutination tests are used to detect:
Which immune cells are primarily involved in antibody dependent cell mediated cytotoxicity (ADCC)?
The major histocompatibility complex (MHC) class I molecules present peptides to which type of cells?
Which of the following is an example of a Type I hypersensitivity reaction?
Which cell surface marker is characteristic of helper T cells?
Which type of hypersensitivity is mediated by immune complexes?
What type of hypersensitivity reaction is involved in contact dermatitis?
Which type of immunity is provided by a vaccine?
Which of the following is a characteristic of the adaptive immune response?
What is the primary role of dendritic cells in the immune system?
questions.correct_answer: B. Presenting antigens to T cells

questions.text: Which molecule is crucial for antigen recognition by T cells?
Which molecule is recognized by helper T cells on antigen presenting cells?
Which cells are responsible for the secondary immune response?
Which bacterial structure contributes to antigenic shift and drug resistance in Neisseria gonorrhoeae?
The primary difference between simple and differential staining is:
Which of the following media is enriched and used to isolate Haemophilus influenzae?

options.label: B
options.text: Chocolate agar with X and V factors

questions.correct_answer: B. Chocolate agar with X and V factors

questions.text: The "string test" is used in identification of:
Clostridium botulinum causes flaccid paralysis by:
A bacterial toxin that causes ADP-ribosylation of G-proteins, leading to increased cAMP and leucocytosis, is:
The bacteria causing diphtheria can be identified by which of the following special stains?
The term "lysogenic conversion" refers to:

options.label: B
options.text: Bacterium gaining new traits due to integrated phage DNA

questions.correct_answer: B. Bacterium gaining new traits due to integrated phage DNA

questions.text: The toxin responsible for gas gangrene has which principal enzymatic activity?
Which of the following features is shared by both Shigella and Salmonella, despite being different genera?
A bacterial sample shows green metallic sheen colonies on EMB agar. What is the most likely identification?
In negative staining, such as with India ink, what is the principle behind capsule visualization?

options.label: A
options.text: Capsule absorbs dye and appears red

options.label: B
options.text: Capsule excludes dye, appearing as a halo

options.label: C
options.text: Dye reacts with mucopolysaccharides in capsule

questions.correct_answer: B. Capsule excludes dye, appearing as a halo

questions.text: In bacterial protein synthesis, what is the target of macrolide antibiotics?
A 2-year-old child develops scalded skin syndrome. Microscopy shown in the image. Which toxin is most likely responsible?
A patient with a prosthetic valve develops infective endocarditis. The culture grows coagulase-negative Staphylococcus. Which is the most important virulence factor?
Bacitracin sensitivity in culture helps differentiate which of the following streptococci?
questions.correct_answer: B. S. pyogenes from S. agalactiae

questions.text: A diabetic patient with trauma to the leg presents with crepitus, pain, and blackish discoloration. Gram stain shows large Gram-positive rods. Which toxin is responsible for tissue necrosis?
A neonate develops meningitis. Gram stain reveals Gram-positive rods with tumbling motility. The pathogen is also CAMP test positive. What is the causative agent?
In diphtheria, which medium helps in demonstrating metachromatic granules?
A 35-year-old man with poor dental hygiene develops multiple discharging sinuses on the jaw. Culture shows filamentous, branching Gram-positive rods. Which is the most likely organism?
A patient with chronic lung disease shows acid-fast, branching filamentous bacteria on Ziehl-Neelsen stain. What is the organism?
A farmer presents with a painless black eschar on the arm. Which is the likely agent?
A hospital outbreak of pseudomembranous colitis is traced to antibiotic use. What is the most appropriate test to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.correct_answer: B. Toxin assay for toxin A/B

questions.text: Which bacterial genus is best identified by reverse CAMP test?
A newborn with poor feeding and opisthotonus posture is diagnosed with neonatal tetanus. Which toxin is responsible for the symptoms?
In Mycobacterium tuberculosis, which structure contributes to virulence and helps in evading phagocytosis?
Which of the following organisms can be grown in cold enrichment culture?
A 10-year-old presents with strawberry tongue, pharyngitis, and sandpaper rash. Which serotype is associated with this presentation?
A 28-year-old man presents with fever, malaise, and an expanding bull’s-eye rash on his leg. He recently returned from a hiking trip. What is the most likely causative organism?

A 24-year-old woman presents with cervicitis and mucopurulent vaginal discharge. NAAT of endocervical swab is positive for Chlamydia trachomatis. Which serovars are typically associated with this presentation?
A man develops painful inguinal buboes and genital ulcers. Serology confirms lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV). What is the best treatment?
A 35-year-old man with HIV presents with bacillary angiomatosis—vascular, red-purple skin nodules. Biopsy shows Warthin-Starry stain–positive bacilli. What is the causative organism?
A patient develops fever, headache, and a maculopapular rash beginning on wrists and ankles and spreading centrally. History reveals tick exposure. What is the likely pathogen?
A 32-year-old man presents with a painless penile ulcer. VDRL is positive, and FTA-ABS is confirmatory. What is the earliest test that would detect the pathogen?

A hospitalized patient develops greenish-blue pus from a burn wound. The wound culture grows Gram-negative rods that are oxidase positive and produce a fruity odour. Which pigment is uniquely produced by this organism?

A veterinarian presents with undulating fever, malaise, and hepatosplenomegaly. Blood culture yields Gram-negative coccobacilli requiring extended incubation. What is the most appropriate diagnostic test in this case?

A middle-aged man with chronic gastritis undergoes endoscopy and is found to have peptic ulcer. Biopsy reveals curved Gram-negative rods. Which factor produced by this organism allows it to survive in the stomach?
A child with diarrhea shows Gram-negative, comma-shaped rods on stool culture. The organism is oxidase-positive and grows at 42°C. What is the most likely organism?
A fisherman presents with rice-water stools and dehydration. Which toxin is responsible for the profuse watery diarrhea in this case?
A 4-year-old unvaccinated child develops epiglottitis with stridor and drooling. Which of the following virulence factors is most important for the causative organism?

A 50-year-old alcoholic man presents with pneumonia and greenish sputum. Gram stain shows Gram-negative rods, oxidase positive, non-lactose fermenting. Culture has a grape-like odour. Which feature contributes most to its antibiotic resistance?
questions.correct_answer: B. Porin loss and efflux pumps

questions.text: A 19-year-old man presents with urethritis. Gram stain of urethral discharge shows intracellular Gram-negative diplococci. Which medium is most appropriate for culture?
A 26-year-old woman with infertility has a positive chlamydial NAAT. Which complication results from chronic infection with Chlamydia trachomatis serovars D–K?
A 25-year-old man presents with dysuria and clear urethral discharge. Gram stain is negative for organisms, but NAAT is positive for Mycoplasma genitalium. What is the treatment of choice?
A 4-year-old child presents with severe cough followed by vomiting. The coughing spells worsen at night. What is the role of pertussis toxin in this condition?

options.label: D
options.text: Stimulates mast cells to release histamine.

questions.correct_answer: B. ADP-ribosylation of G proteins → ↑ cAMP

questions.text: A 40-year-old traveller to India presents with profuse watery diarrhea. Stool microscopy shows no leukocytes. What distinguishes Vibrio cholerae from enteroinvasive organisms?
A 6-year-old child with unvaccinated status presents with meningitis. H. influenzae type b is suspected. Which test best identifies the capsular antigen?

A 33-year-old man develops endocarditis after dental surgery. Blood culture grows pleomorphic Gram-negative bacilli. Which Haemophilus species is part of the HACEK group responsible for this presentation?
Which of the following best explains the persistent antigenic variation in relapsing fever caused by Borrelia recurrentis?
A patient with cystic fibrosis has recurrent pulmonary infections with Gram-negative, oxidase-positive rods producing a mucoid colony. Which virulence factor is critical in this setting?
A 27-year-old hiker presents with arthritis of the knee and Bell’s palsy. Which stage of Lyme disease is most likely?
A 25-year-old female develops genital ulcers and lymphadenopathy. Aspirated pus from a bubo reveals Gram-negative inclusions in monocytes. Which stain best identifies the causative agent?
A 30-year-old male with HIV presents with seizures and brain mass lesions. Serology for Toxoplasma is negative. Biopsy shows Gram-negative coccobacilli with silver stain positivity. Likely organism?
A newborn has bilateral conjunctivitis 7 days after birth. Gram stain shows no organisms. What is the most likely cause and treatment?
A middle-aged man presents with profuse diarrhea. Culture on Campy-BAP agar at 42°C shows curved Gram-negative rods with darting motility. What is the most likely source of infection?
A 28-year-old man presents with dysuria and a mucopurulent urethral discharge. Gram stain shows no organisms. NAAT confirms Chlamydia trachomatis. Which life cycle form is infectious?

A patient with a prosthetic joint develops late-onset sepsis. Culture grows oxidase-positive, non-lactose fermenting Gram-negative bacilli. Which of the following contributes to its persistence on prostheses?
A young adult presents with a chronic cough and diffuse infiltrates on chest X-ray. Cold agglutinin test is positive. Which feature of the organism explains the failure of Gram stain?
A 5-year-old child with incomplete vaccination presents with severe coughing fits and vomiting. The pathogen grows best on which of the following selective media?
A man with occupational exposure to livestock develops undulating fever, night sweats, and back pain. Which blood culture method is preferred for isolating the organism?

A 25-year-old man has diarrhea after consuming undercooked chicken. Stool culture reveals curved, motile, oxidase-positive Gram-negative rods. What neurological complication is associated with this infection?
A 30-year-old woman presents with PID. Culture is negative. NAAT reveals co-infection with Neisseria gonorrhoeae and Chlamydia trachomatis. Why are both treated empirically?

A pregnant woman presents with fever and flu-like illness after consuming unpasteurized soft cheese. Blood culture grows small, Gram-positive rods with tumbling motility. What is the major virulence factor aiding intracellular survival?
A patient presents with watery diarrhea. Culture on TCBS agar reveals yellow colonies. Which biochemical test confirms the diagnosis of Vibrio cholerae?
A patient with pneumonia has silver stain–positive intracellular bacilli and hyponatremia. Which is the most likely cause?
A 23-year-old with tick exposure presents with fever, leukopenia, and thrombocytopenia. No rash is seen. PCR shows Ehrlichia chaffeensis. Which cell type is infected?

A 19-year-old female presents with mucopurulent cervicitis and lower abdominal pain. Culture is negative, but NAAT confirms Chlamydia trachomatis. Which serious complication can result if left untreated?

A 40-year-old man presents with high fever, malaise, and hepatosplenomegaly. He had contact with feral pigs while hunting. Blood culture grows slow-growing Gram-negative coccobacilli. What is the likely diagnosis?
A teenager presents with fever and severe sore throat. Rapid strep test is negative. Cold agglutinin test is positive, and chest X-ray shows interstitial infiltrates. Likely causative agent?
A child with watery diarrhea is found to have infection with Vibrio cholerae. Which mechanism explains the massive fluid loss in this condition?
A 22-year-old man presents with a genital ulcer. Dark-field microscopy reveals tightly coiled, motile spirochetes. He is allergic to penicillin. What is the alternative treatment?
A 38-year-old man presents with fever, lymphadenopathy, and a necrotic skin ulcer after skinning rabbits. Which organism is most likely responsible?
A patient presents with painless genital ulcer and generalized lymphadenopathy. VDRL and FTA-ABS are both positive. Which stage of syphilis is most likely?
A laboratory technician handling a clinical specimen containing an unknown virus is advised to use a Class III biosafety cabinet. What does this suggest about the suspected virus?

options.label: C
options.text: It belongs to Biosafety Level 4 pathogens

options.label: D
options.text: It is unlikely to infect humans.

questions.correct_answer: C. It belongs to Biosafety Level 4 pathogens

questions.text: Which of the following is a defining feature of all RNA viruses except orthomyxoviruses?
Which virus contains reverse transcriptase but does not integrate into the host genome?
Which of the following is a viral structural protein that is typically involved in host cell receptor binding?
A virus with a segmented RNA genome is capable of antigenic shift. Which of the following viruses shares this feature?
Which of the following viruses is most likely to be reactivated in an immunocompromised patient after bone marrow transplantation?
Which structural protein of SARS-CoV-2 binds directly to the host ACE2 receptor?
What is the recommended diagnostic modality for early confirmation of Nipah virus infection?

options.label: C
options.text: RT-PCR from throat swab or CSF

questions.correct_answer: C. RT-PCR from throat swab or CSF

questions.text: Which of the following is the main reservoir of Hantavirus in the wild?
A 35-year-old man with a bat bite develops confusion, hydrophobia, and photophobia. Which of the following is the earliest and most reliable specimen for rabies virus detection?

options.label: B
options.text: Skin biopsy from nape of neck

questions.correct_answer: B. Skin biopsy from nape of neck

questions.text: What is the role of rabies virus glycoprotein G?
questions.correct_answer: C. Antigenicity and host receptor binding

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the genetic structure of influenza viruses?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a linear double-stranded DNA virus

options.label: C
options.text: It consists of multiple negative-sense RNA segments

questions.correct_answer: C. It consists of multiple negative-sense RNA segments

questions.text: What is the mechanism of paralysis in poliomyelitis?
questions.correct_answer: C. Destruction of anterior horn cells

questions.text: A patient develops transient aplastic crisis after parvovirus B19 infection. Which of the following conditions predisposes to this complication?
A child born to an HIV-positive mother tests negative for HIV at birth. Which test should be used to confirm the infection status in the first few months?
A 45-year-old man presents with a vesicular rash over the left thorax in a dermatomal pattern. Which virus is most likely involved?
Which of the following herpesviruses is associated with Kaposi's sarcoma in HIV patients?
A patient with a bone marrow transplant develops interstitial pneumonia. Biopsy shows "owl eye" inclusions. Which virus is most likely responsible?
A 45-year-old man with chronic hepatitis B has serology showing HBsAg+, HBeAg–, and anti-HBe+. His HBV DNA levels are high. What mutation is most likely present?
Which of the following statements about Hepatitis C virus is TRUE?

options.label: A
options.text: There is a highly effective vaccine available

options.label: B
options.text: Reinfection is rare after successful treatment

options.label: C
options.text: It is a double-stranded RNA virus

options.label: D
options.text: It shows a high degree of genetic variability

questions.correct_answer: D. It shows a high degree of genetic variability

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient with chronic hepatitis D infection shows presence of HBsAg but absence of HBcAg. What does this imply?

options.label: B
options.text: Superinfection with HDV on chronic HBV

questions.correct_answer: B. Superinfection with HDV on chronic HBV

questions.text: Which of the following is the most effective strategy for eradication of poliovirus?
questions.correct_answer: B. Use of oral polio vaccine (OPV)

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents with vesicular lesions on the tongue and buccal mucosa, along with maculopapular rash on palms and soles. Which is the most likely virus?
A young adult presents with acute chest pain, elevated cardiac enzymes, and ECG changes. PCR of endomyocardial tissue shows viral RNA. Which virus is most likely?
Ebola virus exhibits which of the following structural features?
Which virus family uses reverse transcription but is not a retrovirus?
Which viral encephalitis shows predilection for temporal lobes?
The most effective way to prevent HPV-related cancers is:

A 4yearold child presents with a high fever followed by the appearance of a rash that starts on the face and spreads to the trunk. Koplik spots are observed in the oral cavity. Which virus is the most likely cause?
A 25yearold pregnant woman presents with fever, joint pain, and a rash. She is found to have Zika virus infection. Which of the following complications is most concerning for the fetus?
A barefoot farmer presents with iron-deficiency anemia. Stool microscopy reveals segmented eggs. What is the most likely route of infection?
A child from an endemic area presents with diarrhea and stunted growth. Microscopy reveals bile-stained, mamillated eggs. Which complication is most likely?
A woman presents with frothy vaginal discharge and vaginal itching. Wet mount of vaginal fluid shows motile flagellated organisms. What is the treatment of choice?
A patient presents with a slowly enlarging cyst in the liver. Imaging reveals a well-circumscribed lesion with daughter cysts. Which feature on aspiration confirms hydatid disease?
A 6-year-old boy in a malaria-endemic area has recurrent malaria episodes with dormant hepatic stages. Which species is responsible?
A 30-year-old man develops chronic lymphatic obstruction and scrotal swelling after years in a filariasis-endemic region. What is the vector for this condition?
A young girl presents with itching and skin nodules over the legs. She is from a village near a fast-flowing river in Africa. Skin snip shows microfilariae. Likely causative agent?
A 40-year-old man presents with intermittent diarrhea. Ova in stool have a large operculum and are bile stained. He admits to eating undercooked freshwater crab. Which parasite is responsible?
A 3-year-old child from a tropical country presents with foul-smelling diarrhea. Stool wet mount shows oocysts that auto fluoresce under UV light. Which parasite is most likely?
A man presents with chronic eosinophilia and GI symptoms. Stool examination shows larvae, not eggs. Which test confirms the diagnosis?
questions.correct_answer: D. Stool culture with Baermann technique

questions.text: A child presents with perianal itching. The mother applied transparent tape to the perianal region in the morning, and microscopy shows eggs. What is the most appropriate follow-up step?

options.label: B
options.text: Repeat testing for ova in 2 weeks

questions.correct_answer: C. Treat child and close contacts

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with haematuria and dysuria. Cystoscopy shows bladder wall fibrosis. Urine microscopy reveals eggs with a terminal spine. What long-term complication is associated with this infection?
A traveller returns from South America with fever, swollen eyelid (Romaña sign), and cardiomegaly. Which stage of the organism is detected in blood during acute illness?
A 2-year-old child in a daycare develops greasy, foul-smelling stools and weight loss. Stool antigen test is positive. What is the best treatment?
A boy from Africa develops seizures and hydrocephalus. CSF shows motile flagellated organisms. What is the likely pathogen?
A child from a rural area presents with rectal prolapse and iron-deficiency anemia. Stool microscopy shows barrel-shaped eggs with bipolar plugs. Which parasite is the cause?
A woman presents with recurrent seizures. CT scan shows multiple calcified brain lesions. Which test confirms the parasitic cause?

A 29-year-old woman returns from a village with fever, hepatosplenomegaly, and mild jaundice. Blood smear shows ring-shaped parasites inside RBCs with occasional multiple infections per cell. What is the most likely pathogen?
A young adult with a history of eating raw freshwater fish develops obstructive jaundice. Imaging shows biliary tract dilatation. Which parasite is the most likely cause?

A man is admitted with fever, chills, hemolytic anemia, and jaundice. He recently returned from the northeastern U.S. and had a tick bite. Blood smear shows tetrads in RBCs (Maltese cross). What is the diagnosis?
A 35-year-old man has haematuria and is diagnosed with squamous cell carcinoma of the bladder. He lived in Egypt for several years. What is the most likely parasitic cause?
A girl has seizures. CT scan shows a single ring-enhancing lesion. She owns pigs and consumes pork regularly. Which diagnostic test is most sensitive?
questions.correct_answer: D. ELISA for Taenia solium antibodies

questions.text: A child from an endemic area presents with massive splenomegaly, pancytopenia, and hyperpigmented skin ("black sickness"). Bone marrow biopsy shows amastigotes. What is the treatment of choice?
A man returns from Brazil with skin ulcers, mucosal erosion, and enlarged lymph nodes. Microscopy of a biopsy shows amastigotes. What is the likely species?
A 12-year-old presents with abdominal discomfort and visible motile worms in stool. Stool shows bile-stained, round, corticated eggs. What is the diagnosis?
A fisherman from Southeast Asia has mild jaundice and abdominal pain. Stool exam shows operculated eggs. What is the chronic complication of this infection?
A child presents with anemia and abdominal pain. He has a history of playing barefoot. Stool microscopy shows eggs with thin shells and segmented ovum. What is the diagnosis?
A patient develops respiratory distress, urticaria, and GI symptoms after starting steroids for asthma. Larvae are seen in sputum and stool. What is the most likely cause?
A patient develops progressive fatigue and pallor. He admits to eating raw freshwater fish. Stool shows operculated eggs. Labs reveal low vitamin B12. What is the cause?
A child presents with abdominal discomfort and anal itching. Perianal tape prep reveals flattened-side eggs. What is the most common complication?
A patient has diarrhea and microscopic stool exam reveals teardrop-shaped trophozoites with two nuclei and four flagella. Which of the following contributes most to its pathogenicity?
A woman in late pregnancy is found to be IgM positive for Toxoplasma gondii. What fetal abnormality is most likely if vertical transmission occurs?
A man presents with weight loss and abdominal discomfort. He frequently eats raw beef. Which parasite is likely and how is it differentiated?
questions.correct_answer: B. Taenia saginata – scolex without hooks

questions.text: A 40yearold man presents with chronic diarrhea, weight loss, and abdominal pain. Stool examination reveals oval cysts with four nuclei. Which organism is most likely responsible?
Which of the following is the definitive host for Toxoplasma gondii?
The infective form of Leishmania donovani for humans is:
Kala-azar is diagnosed serologically using which of the following tests?
The ‘nurse cell’ formation is a hallmark of:
Which parasite causes 'Winterbottom sign'?
A patient has subcutaneous swellings and migratory skin lesions. Calabar swellings are associated with:
A 55-year-old patient presents with a verrucous skin lesion over the leg. Histopathology shows brown-pigmented “sclerotic bodies” or “copper pennies.” Identify the condition:
Which dermatophyte infects only skin and nails, but not hair?
Which test is useful for the rapid diagnosis of tinea infections?
A 45-year-old man presents with fever, weight loss, and hepatosplenomegaly. Bone marrow biopsy reveals small intracellular yeast forms within macrophages. What is the most likely organism?
A middle-aged man from Arizona develops cough, fever, and chest pain. Biopsy reveals large spherules filled with endospores. What is the most likely diagnosis?
A South American farmer presents with chronic mucocutaneous ulcers and lymphadenopathy. Biopsy shows “pilot wheel” yeast forms. What is the causative agent?
Which of the following statements about dimorphic fungi is TRUE?

options.label: B
options.text: They grow as yeast in the environment

options.label: D
options.text: They are mold in cold and yeast in heat.

questions.correct_answer: D. They are mold in cold and yeast in heat.

questions.text: A forestry worker presents with ulcerated skin lesions, productive cough, and lung nodules. Sputum culture grows broad-based budding yeast. What is the likely organism?
Talaromyces (Penicillium) marneffei causes disseminated infection primarily in which group?
questions.correct_answer: C. HIV-infected individuals in Southeast Asia

questions.text: Which of the following fungi is associated with caves and bat droppings?
Which of the following best differentiates Candida albicans from non-albicans Candida species?
What is the natural reservoir for Cryptococcus neoformans?
Which virulence factor is primarily responsible for the pathogenicity of Cryptococcus neoformans?
A patient with asthma develops worsening wheezing and brownish sputum. Labs reveal high IgE and eosinophilia. Sputum culture shows Aspergillus. Likely diagnosis?
Which antifungal is first line for treatment of invasive pulmonary aspergillosis?
A 30-year-old female with IUD develops chronic pelvic pain. Endometrial biopsy shows budding yeast and pseudohyphae. Most likely organism?
Which fungus can cause catheter-related fungemia and forms biofilms that are resistant to antifungals?
Which of the following best characterizes Sporothrix schenckii in tissue and culture respectively?

options.label: A
options.text: Yeast form in tissue, hyphal form in culture

options.label: C
options.text: Spherule in tissue, yeast in culture

questions.correct_answer: A. Yeast form in tissue, hyphal form in culture

questions.text: All are true regarding Malassezia furfur EXCEPT:

options.label: A
options.text: It is lipophilic and requires fatty acids for growth

options.label: B
options.text: Shows “spaghetti and meatballs” appearance in KOH mount

options.label: C
options.text: It causes hypo- or hyperpigmented macules

options.label: D
options.text: It is dimorphic and invasive in immunocompetent hosts.

questions.correct_answer: D. It is dimorphic and invasive in immunocompetent hosts.

questions.text: A 45-year-old diabetic male presents with facial pain, orbital swelling, black nasal discharge, and cranial nerve palsies. KOH mount of nasal swab shows broad, ribbon-like, aseptate hyphae. Which of the following is most accurate regarding the causative organism?

options.label: A
options.text: It shows narrow angle branching and septate hyphae

options.label: B
options.text: It is commonly isolated on Sabouraud's agar as black pigmented colony

options.label: C
options.text: It invades via angioinvasion leading to tissue necrosis

questions.correct_answer: C. It invades via angioinvasion leading to tissue necrosis
